On either side of the marked point, the red-portioned white stripes of a traffic island extend straight into an octagonal-shaped road island perched in the crossroads. This traffic island contrasts with a more traditional traffic roundabout that overlays the octagonal island copy in the image just one panel up. In China, U-turns on a multi-lane road are not always allowed and considered as civil offenses at intersections with octagonal traffic islands and about 12 times as frequently in unmarked intersections lacking sidewalks, so instead, the vehicles must pursue a U-turn onto the adjacent parallel road segment at such `nodal points` to reverse direction. To do so, the drivers must be certain the intersection's crossing lanes will clear of automobiles before proceeding. Beijing uses the octagonal island style to provide a safe object for vehicles to abut and thus provide warning to oncoming drivers that would be more difficult to foresee should traditional, circular roundabout layouts be used instead. 

Considering these aspects, the lane designations can be determined as follows:
